channel.title: Why so slow?
channel.description: Alright, so I finally decided to hop off the Winshit wagon and install Fedora... I'm sitting here trying to download some packages, and I have why question... Why are my internet speeds significantly slower on Fedora? For instance, I'm downloading Google Chrome... On Windows, it finishes the download in seconds, and on Fedora its saying its going to take an hour+. Just loading web pages is significantly slower... So, am I going to have to deal with this, or is there some settings I have to change, or what?

item.title: Why so slow?
item.dc:creator: @Teh_Dew1 Teh_Dew
item.description:
@Teh_Dew1 wrote:

I had the same issue when I first started using Linux back in 2008. My problem was my old Network card, as people have mentioned below.

Read full topic

item.title: Why so slow?
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

3kb/s is much less than 10mbit

@op: Wired or Wireless? What hardware/driver? Anything in dmesg that looks relevant?

Read full topic

item.title: Why so slow?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Did you verify IPv6 was actually disabled with ‘ifconfig’ or something similar?

Another thing you have to be careful about is your ethernet settings, like speed (10mbit, 100mbit, 1000mbit) and duplex (half-duplex, full-duplex). Most of the time auto-negotiation works, sometimes it doesn’t.

Read full topic

item.title: Why so slow?
item.dc:creator: @m.dog311 m.dog311
item.description:
@m.dog311 wrote:

Alright, so I’ve tried what you guys have suggested, and no luck. I attempted to download Ubuntu & live disk it to see if I could narrow it down to being just a problem with Fedora, but with these amazing 3kb/s download speeds, I don’t think that will be happening.

Read full topic

item.title: Why so slow?
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“abraham2119, post:5, topic:399854”][quote author=T4_ link=topic=496969.msg3633724#msg3633724 date=1308439034]
An operating system can’t effect download speeds too much (saying too much because of the limitation Windows has enabled by default).
[/quote]network drivers are different…[/quote]
You’d have to have a pretty shit driver…

Read full topic

item.title: Why so slow?
item.dc:creator: @Cheese_Police c|p
item.description:
@Cheese_Police wrote:

I don’t think this is as likely as some of the other problems described, but one of the times I switched from Windows to Linux my download rate had dropped a lot and it turned out to be that my NIC failed at the exact same time I switched.

Read full topic

item.title: Why so slow?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Wonder if it’s a strange ipv6 problem with your router, try disabling IPv6 and see what happens. To do this, just put ‘ipv6.disable=1’ on your boot line in GRUB:

http://wan.pengganas.net/entry/ubuntu-karmic-disable-ipv6-using-grub/

Something like that, could be different if you are using GRUB legacy.

Read full topic

item.title: Why so slow?
item.dc:creator: @m.dog311 m.dog311
item.description:
@m.dog311 wrote:

Alright Niall, I’ll try that. Another question, has anyone else ever had trouble with their computer speakers when using Linux? My built in speakers work fine, but when I plug something into the headphone jack I get no sound from anything. However, if I partially plug something into it, I get sound from both. Most people are saying to make sure their not muted in Alsamixer, which is telling me that everything is unmuted but at 00 sound level, which can’t be changed. I’m thinking thats probably a driver error, but I don’t know…

Edit:
I just noticed that I have about 160 updates that need to be done. I’m going to update those and see if anything changes.

Read full topic

item.title: Why so slow?
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

it might not be the problem you’re having, but try getting the dns servers from your router and setting them manually in NetworkManager, I had a problem a few years back where no linux distro could set the dns up properly so loading webpages took significantly longer and I had slower download speeds

Read full topic

item.title: Why so slow?
item.dc:creator: @abraham2119 abraham2119
item.description:
@abraham2119 wrote:

[quote=“T4_, post:2, topic:399854”]An operating system can’t effect download speeds too much (saying too much because of the limitation Windows has enabled by default).[/quote]network drivers are different…

Read full topic

item.title: Why so slow?
item.dc:creator: @lawl lawl
item.description:
@lawl wrote:

bizarre, sounds like it might be a problem with some weird low level stuff or something wrong with your configuration

Read full topic

item.title: Why so slow?
item.dc:creator: @m.dog311 m.dog311
item.description:
@m.dog311 wrote:

I don’t see what else it could be… Konqueror is slow, yum is slow, etc. I am getting on average 20-30kb/s download speeds since I switched Fedora, when I was getting between 200 & 500 kb/s on Windows.

Read full topic

item.title: Why so slow?
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

An operating system can’t effect download speeds too much (saying too much because of the limitation Windows has enabled by default).

Read full topic
